Posts.Content: On Mar 11, 2013 6:33 PM Katrinadolls wrote: I had reconstruction that worked, but like most of us the other one was sagging, so my plastic surgeon (a women ) did a breast augmentation on the saggy one, very good, a little smaller than my reconstructed one but with a small pad in my bra it looks great. Made a big difference in how I felt! I can now wear t-shirts. I however have a different problem, I have chest pain on the side of my surgery, it took about a year to start, it is a burning feeling first, then awful pain that is like a knife across my chest, it doesn't last too long and to describe it better it is like an awful Charlie horse then the pain leaves but you can still feel where it has been. This happens very sporadically, some times two days in a row, or once in two weeks, or it has even happened an hour apart. Just about the time I think it is gone it happens again, and a lot of the time it is in the early morning (3AM) and never while I am active, and once when I was driving, had to pull off the road! Posts.Content: On Dec 20, 2012 6:31 AM Makingway wrote: There is a website devoted to this issue it's called taxotears. There is a 6-8% risk of permanent hair loss when taxotere is the chemo regimen. It's unfortunate the doctors gloss over that fact. Especially so when hair loss can be prevented entirely by using a cold cap during chemo. Penguin cold caps and Elastogel caps are what is available to the public. THIS IS NOT FAIR THAT WE ARE NOT TOLD A LOT OF THINGS THAT MAY HELP US AND HURT THE CHANCE OF THEM...MAKE MONEY OR SEEM TO BE HEROS. IM SO SORRY IT HAPPEN TO ANY OF US. NOW WHAT CAN WE DO TO BE HELPED WITH THESE SIDE EFFECTS?
